verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD:
verses.comment: Jeremiah frequently introduces sections with this phrase, emphasizing the prophetic authority of the message.

verses.text: "Arise and go down to the potter's house, and there I will let you hear My words."
verses.comment: God often uses visual aids or enacted parables for prophetic teaching, as seen with the potter's house. cf. Isaiah 29:16; Romans 9:21.

verses.text: So I went down to the potter's house, and there he was working at his wheel.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s obedience shows the importance of responding to God’s direction in faith, even before the full revelation is given (link: Acts 9:11).

verses.text: And the vessel he was making of clay was marred in the potter's hand; so he remade it into another vessel, as it seemed good to the potter to make.
verses.comment: The image of God as potter and His people as clay is repeated throughout Scripture (Isaiah 64:8). This stresses God’s sovereign right to shape His people according to His will.

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to me:
verses.comment: This repeated formula underscores the direct divine authority behind Jeremiah’s prophetic message (see Jer. 1:4).

verses.text: "O house of Israel, can I not do with you as this potter has done? declares the LORD. Behold, like the clay in the potter's hand, so are you in My hand, O house of Israel."
verses.comment: God's sovereignty over His people is analogous to the potter’s control over the clay (cf. Romans 9:21). This points to God’s authority and the need for humble cooperation with His plan.

verses.text: "If at any time I speak concerning a nation or a kingdom, to uproot, to tear down, or to destroy it,
verses.comment: God employs these same verbs in His commission of Jeremiah (Jer. 1:10), underlining the consistency of His warnings and promises.

verses.text: and if that nation turns from its evil, I will relent concerning the disaster that I intended to bring upon it."
verses.comment: This reveals God's mercy and conditional judgment; repentance leads to forgiveness (cf. Jonah 3:10). God’s justice is matched by His willingness to forgive when people turn to Him, reflecting both Old and New Testament patterns (Luke 15:7).

verses.text: "And if at another time I speak concerning a nation or kingdom to build and to plant it,
verses.comment: ‘To build and to plant’ echoes Jer. 1:10. Blessing and restoration are contingent on obedience.

verses.text: and if it does evil in My sight, not listening to My voice, then I will relent of the good with which I said I would bless it."
verses.comment: God’s promises and threats are both true and just, but require faithful response. The faithfulness of the people remains essential for blessing.

verses.text: "Now therefore, say to the men of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem: Thus says the LORD: Behold, I am shaping disaster against you and devising a plan against you. Turn now, every one of you, from his evil way, and mend your ways and your deeds."
verses.comment: National repentance is possible even under threat of judgment. God’s desire is always the reformation of His people rather than destruction (cf. 2 Chronicles 7:14).

verses.text: "But they will say, 'It is hopeless. For we will follow our own plans, and each of us will act according to the stubbornness of his evil heart.'"
verses.comment: Human stubbornness is contrasted to God’s patient mercy. Hardness of heart is a recurring Old Testament warning and a key issue Jesus addresses (Matthew 19:8).

verses.text: Therefore thus says the LORD: "Ask among the nations, Who has heard the like of this? The virgin Israel has done a most horrible thing.
verses.comment: Israel’s sin is portrayed as shocking even by the standards of the surrounding nations (cf. Jer. 2:10-11). The image of ‘virgin Israel’ highlights the original holiness and calling of God’s people.

verses.text: Does the snow of Lebanon leave the rocks of the field? Do the cold flowing waters from a distance dry up?
verses.comment: The rhetorical questions emphasize Israel’s unnatural apostasy. The enduring waters symbolize God’s faithfulness, which Israel has abandoned.

verses.text: But My people have forgotten Me; they burn incense to worthless idols, and they have stumbled from their ways, from the ancient paths, to walk in bypaths, not the highway,
verses.comment: The concept of 'ancient paths' points to the tradition and continuity of faith that God called Israel to uphold—a principle later echoed in maintaining the faith handed down from the apostles (cf. 2 Thess. 2:15).

verses.text: making their land a horror, a perpetual object of scorn. Everyone who passes by it will be appalled and shake his head.
verses.comment: A classic statement of the consequences of covenant unfaithfulness. The idea of nations becoming a 'byword' links to Deut. 28:37.

verses.text: Like an east wind, I will scatter them before the enemy; I will show them My back and not My face, in the day of their calamity."
verses.comment: God’s judgment removes His presence—a tragic reversal of the blessing to have God ‘face’ His people. Contrast with the priestly blessing (Num. 6:25-26).

verses.text: Then they said, 'Come, let us make plans against Jeremiah—for the law will not perish from the priest, nor counsel from the wise, nor the word from the prophet. Come, let us strike him with the tongue, and let us not pay attention to any of his words.'
verses.comment: Jeremiah is persecuted as were many prophets, foreshadowing later opposition to Christ and the apostles (see Matthew 23:34).

verses.text: Hear me, O LORD, and listen to the voice of those who contend with me!
verses.comment: Jeremiah offers a prayer of complaint and seeking vindication, echoing the psalmists’ cries in times of persecution.

verses.text: Should good be repaid with evil? Yet they have dug a pit for my life. Remember how I stood before You to speak good for them, to turn away Your wrath from them.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s role as intercessor prefigures Christ’s mediating ministry. He pleads for those who persecute him, a quality that Jesus calls His followers to imitate (Luke 23:34).

verses.text: Therefore, give their children over to famine; deliver them over to the power of the sword. Let their wives become childless and widows, let their men be struck down by pestilence, their young men struck down by the sword in battle.
verses.comment: Despite this harsh imprecatory prayer, Jeremiah’s plea for justice springs from deep pain and zeal for God’s righteousness. He entrusts ultimate justice to the Lord.

verses.text: Let a cry be heard from their houses, when You suddenly bring raiders upon them. For they have dug a pit to capture me, and hidden snares for my feet.
verses.comment: The language of snares and traps echoes the Psalms; God’s prophets often suffer the plots of those who reject God’s Word.

verses.text: But You, O LORD, know all their plans to kill me. Do not forgive their iniquity or blot out their sin from Your sight. Let them be overthrown before You; deal with them in the time of Your anger.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s prayer ends the chapter with an appeal to God’s justice. Later teaching will clarify the call to forgive enemies (cf. Matthew 5:44), but this reveals the burden of prophetic ministry under the Old Covenant. As Christian readers look ahead, Christ fulfills both the prophetic office and the perfect forgiveness greater than Jeremiah’s lament (see Hebrews 1:1–2).
